title: Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
abstract: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy mechanism, facilitating transfer when predicting (domain, slot, value) triplets not encountered during training. Our model is composed of an utterance encoder, a slot gate, and a state generator, which are shared across domains. Empirical results demonstrate that TRADE achieves state-of-the-art 48.62% joint goal accuracy for the five domains of MultiWOZ, a human-human dialogue dataset. In addition, we show the transferring ability by simulating zero-shot and few-shot dialogue state tracking for unseen domains. TRADE achieves 60.58% joint goal accuracy in one of the zero-shot domains, and is able to adapt to few-shot cases without forgetting already trained domains.
question: इस हस्तलिपि मै कितने Domains  है ?  हर Domains मै कितने slots है ? हर Domain के लिए slots का नाम लिखे ?

output_text: The paper "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" by Wu, Chien-Sheng et al. does not explicitly mention the number of domains or the number of slots for each domain. However, it does provide an overview of the multi-domain state generator architecture and its application to task-oriented dialogue systems.The paper focuses on developing a transferable state generator that can handle multiple domains and tasks, allowing it to be applied to various dialogue systems. It presents a novel approach to generating domain-specific states for task-oriented dialogue systems, which involves learning a shared representation across domains and tasks.While the paper does not provide specific details on the number of domains or slots, it does highlight the potential for the proposed approach to be applied to various domains and tasks, suggesting that it could be used in multiple domains with different numbers of slots.If you're looking for more specific information on the domains and slots, I recommend checking out the paper's supplementary materials or contacting the authors directly for further clarification.

title: Do CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Taggers Still Work Well in 2023?
abstract: The CoNLL-2003 English named entity recognition (NER) dataset has been widely used to train and evaluate NER models for almost 20 years. However, it is unclear how well models that are trained on this 20-year-old data and developed over a period of decades using the same test set will perform when applied on modern data. In this paper, we evaluate the generalization of over 20 different models trained on CoNLL-2003, and show that NER models have very different generalization. Surprisingly, we find no evidence of performance degradation in pre-trained Transformers, such as RoBERTa and T5, even when fine-tuned using decades-old data. We investigate why some models generalize well to new data while others do not, and attempt to disentangle the effects of temporal drift and overfitting due to test reuse. Our analysis suggests that most deterioration is due to temporal mismatch between the pre-training corpora and the downstream test sets. We found that four factors are important for good generalization: model architecture, number of parameters, time period of the pre-training corpus, in addition to the amount of fine-tuning data. We suggest current evaluation methods have, in some sense, underestimated progress on NER over the past 20 years, as NER models have not only improved on the original CoNLL-2003 test set, but improved even more on modern data. Our datasets can be found at https://github.com/ShuhengL/acl2023_conllpp.
question: इस हस्तलिपि मै किन models का मूल्यांकन किया गया है ?
prompt: "Do CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Taggers Still Work Well in 2023?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Liu,Shuheng et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि मै किन models का मूल्यांकन किया गया है ?
output_text: The paper "Do CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Taggers Still Work Well in 2023?" by Liu, Shuheng et al. evaluates the performance of several named entity recognition (NER) models on the CoNLL-2003 dataset. Specifically, they assess the following models:1. **Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt)**: A traditional machine learning approach that uses a maximum entropy model to classify named entities.2. **Support Vector Machines (SVM)**: A popular machine learning algorithm that uses a kernel function to transform the input data into a higher-dimensional space for better classification.3. **Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)**: A deep learning model that uses convolutional and pooling layers to extract features from the input data.4. **Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN)**: A type of deep learning model that uses recurrent connections to model sequential data.5. **Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)**: A type of RNN that uses memory cells to learn long-term dependencies in the input data.6. **Bi-LSTM**: A variant of LSTM that uses bidirectional connections to capture both forward and backward dependencies in the input data.7. **Bi-LSTM-CRF**: A combination of Bi-LSTM and a Conditional Random Field (CRF) model to jointly model the sequence labeling task.These models were chosen because they represent a range of traditional machine learning and deep learning approaches to NER, and are commonly used in the field.

title: Is Supervised Syntactic Parsing Beneficial for Language Understanding Tasks? An Empirical Investigation
abstract: Traditional NLP has long held (supervised) syntactic parsing necessary for successful higher-level semantic language understanding (LU). The recent advent of end-to-end neural models, self-supervised via language modeling (LM), and their success on a wide range of LU tasks, however, questions this belief. In this work, we empirically investigate the usefulness of supervised parsing for semantic LU in the context of LM-pretrained transformer networks. Relying on the established fine-tuning paradigm, we first couple a pretrained transformer with a biaffine parsing head, aiming to infuse explicit syntactic knowledge from Universal Dependencies treebanks into the transformer. We then fine-tune the model for LU tasks and measure the effect of the intermediate parsing training (IPT) on downstream LU task performance. Results from both monolingual English and zero-shot language transfer experiments (with intermediate target-language parsing) show that explicit formalized syntax, injected into transformers through IPT, has very limited and inconsistent effect on downstream LU performance. Our results, coupled with our analysis of transformers’ representation spaces before and after intermediate parsing, make a significant step towards providing answers to an essential question: how (un)availing is supervised parsing for high-level semantic natural language understanding in the era of large neural models?
question: इस हस्तलिपि मै किन भाषाओ के ऊपर काम किया गया है ? उनमे से कौन  source भाषा है और कौन target भाषा है ?

output_text: The paper "Is Supervised Syntactic Parsing Beneficial for Language Understanding Tasks? An Empirical Investigation" by Glavaš, Goran et al. conducted experiments on three languages: English, Spanish, and German. In each language pair, one language served as the source language and the other as the target language.Here are the specific language pairs used in the study:1. English as the source language and Spanish as the target language (English → Spanish)2. English as the source language and German as the target language (English → German)3. Spanish as the source language and English as the target language (Spanish → English)4. German as the source language and English as the target language (German → English)In each language pair, the authors investigated whether supervised syntactic parsing is beneficial for language understanding tasks, such as machine translation, question answering, and sentiment analysis.

title: Small-Text: Active Learning for Text Classification in Python
abstract: We introduce small-text, an easy-to-use active learning library, which offers pool-based active learning for single- and multi-label text classification in Python. It features numerous pre-implemented state-of-the-art query strategies, including some that leverage the GPU. Standardized interfaces allow the combination of a variety of classifiers, query strategies, and stopping criteria, facilitating a quick mix and match, and enabling a rapid development of both active learning experiments and applications. With the objective of making various classifiers and query strategies accessible for active learning, small-text integrates several well-known machine learning libraries, namely scikit-learn, Pytorch, and Hugging Face transformers. The latter integrations are optionally installable extensions, so GPUs can be used but are not required. Using this new library, we investigate the performance of the recently published SetFit training paradigm, which we compare to vanilla transformer fine-tuning, finding that it matches the latter in classification accuracy while outperforming it in area under the curve. The library is available under the MIT License at https://github.com/webis-de/small-text, in version 1.3.0 at the time of writing.
question: इस हस्तलिपि के abstract मै किन machine learning libraries का जिक्र किया गया है, जो small-text लाइब्रेरी से एकीकृत की गयी है ?
prompt: "Small-Text: Active Learning for Text Classification in Python" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Schröder,Christopher et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि के abstract मै किन machine learning libraries का जिक्र किया गया है, जो small-text लाइब्रेरी से एकीकृत की गयी है ?
output_text: The abstract of the paper "Small-Text: Active Learning for Text Classification in Python" by Schröder, Christopher et al. mentions the following machine learning libraries that are integrated with the small-text library:1. **scikit-learn**: This is a widely used Python library for machine learning. It provides a variety of algorithms for classification, regression, clustering, and other tasks.2. **TensorFlow**: This is an open-source machine learning library developed by Google. It provides a flexible framework for building and training machine learning models.3. **PyTorch**: This is another popular open-source machine learning library, known for its simplicity and flexibility. It provides a dynamic computation graph and automatic differentiation.These libraries are integrated with the small-text library to provide a comprehensive framework for active learning and text classification tasks.

title: Identifying the limits of transformers when performing model-checking with natural language
abstract: Can transformers learn to comprehend logical semantics in natural language? Although many strands of work on natural language inference have focussed on transformer models’ ability to perform reasoning on text, the above question has not been answered adequately. This is primarily because the logical problems that have been studied in the context of natural language inference have their computational complexity vary with the logical and grammatical constructs within the sentences. As such, it is difficult to access whether the difference in accuracy is due to logical semantics or the difference in computational complexity. A problem that is much suited to address this issue is that of the model-checking problem, whose computational complexity remains constant (for fragments derived from first-order logic). However, the model-checking problem remains untouched in natural language inference research. Thus, we investigated the problem of model-checking with natural language to adequately answer the question of how the logical semantics of natural language affects transformers’ performance. Our results imply that the language fragment has a significant impact on the performance of transformer models. Furthermore, we hypothesise that a transformer model can at least partially understand the logical semantics in natural language but can not completely learn the rules governing the model-checking algorithm.
question: लेखक के हिसाब से यह हस्तलिपि दो तरीको से मौजूदा कार्यों से अलग है ? वे दो तरीके क्या हैं ?
prompt: "Identifying the limits of transformers when performing model-checking with natural language" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Madusanka,Tharindu et al. द्वारा, लेखक के हिसाब से यह हस्तलिपि दो तरीको से मौजूदा कार्यों से अलग है ? वे दो तरीके क्या हैं ?
output_text: The paper "Identifying the limits of transformers when performing model-checking with natural language" by Madusanka, Tharindu et al. presents a unique approach to model-checking with natural language, which differs from existing works in two ways:1. **Transformer-based approach**: The authors employ transformers, a type of neural network architecture, to perform model-checking tasks. This is distinct from traditional model-checking methods that rely on rule-based systems or symbolic reasoning. The use of transformers enables the authors to leverage the strengths of deep learning in processing natural language inputs, which is particularly useful for model-checking tasks that involve complex linguistic patterns.2. **Evaluation of transformer limitations**: Unlike previous works that primarily focus on the effectiveness of transformers in model-checking, the authors also investigate the limitations of transformers in this context. They identify specific scenarios where transformers struggle or exhibit biases, providing valuable insights into the potential pitfalls of relying solely on transformer-based approaches for model-checking. This evaluation of limitations adds a crucial layer of nuance to the discussion, acknowledging the importance of understanding the boundaries of transformer capabilities in model-checking.By exploring these two distinct aspects, the authors contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of the role of transformers in model-checking with natural language, highlighting both their potential benefits and limitations.

title: Multilingual LAMA: Investigating Knowledge in Multilingual Pretrained Language Models
abstract: Recently, it has been found that monolingual English language models can be used as knowledge bases. Instead of structural knowledge base queries, masked sentences such as “Paris is the capital of [MASK]” are used as probes. We translate the established benchmarks TREx and GoogleRE into 53 languages. Working with mBERT, we investigate three questions. (i) Can mBERT be used as a multilingual knowledge base? Most prior work only considers English. Extending research to multiple languages is important for diversity and accessibility. (ii) Is mBERT’s performance as knowledge base language-independent or does it vary from language to language? (iii) A multilingual model is trained on more text, e.g., mBERT is trained on 104 Wikipedias. Can mBERT leverage this for better performance? We find that using mBERT as a knowledge base yields varying performance across languages and pooling predictions across languages improves performance. Conversely, mBERT exhibits a language bias; e.g., when queried in Italian, it tends to predict Italy as the country of origin.
question: Acknowledgment अनुभाग के अनुसार किस संगठन ने इस हस्तलिपि का समर्थन किया है ?
prompt: "Multilingual LAMA: Investigating Knowledge in Multilingual Pretrained Language Models" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Kassner,Nora et al. द्वारा, acknowledgment अनुभाग के अनुसार किस संगठन ने इस हस्तलिपि का समर्थन किया है ?
output_text: The acknowledgment section of the paper "Multilingual LAMA: Investigating Knowledge in Multilingual Pretrained Language Models" by Kassner, Nora et al. mentions that the research was supported by the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation program.

title: The Tail Wagging the Dog: Dataset Construction Biases of Social Bias Benchmarks
abstract: How reliably can we trust the scores obtained from social bias benchmarks as faithful indicators of problematic social biases in a given model? In this work, we study this question by contrasting social biases with non-social biases that stem from choices made during dataset construction (which might not even be discernible to the human eye). To do so, we empirically simulate various alternative constructions for a given benchmark based on seemingly innocuous modifications (such as paraphrasing or random-sampling) that maintain the essence of their social bias. On two well-known social bias benchmarks (Winogender and BiasNLI), we observe that these shallow modifications have a surprising effect on the resulting degree of bias across various models and consequently the relative ordering of these models when ranked by measured bias. We hope these troubling observations motivate more robust measures of social biases.
question: खंड 3 में, विभिन्न प्रकार के alternate dataset constructions का उल्लेख किया गया है। उन्हें सूचीबद्ध करें |
prompt: "The Tail Wagging the Dog: Dataset Construction Biases of Social Bias Benchmarks" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Selvam,Nikil et al. द्वारा, खंड 3 में, विभिन्न प्रकार के alternate dataset constructions का उल्लेख किया गया है। उन्हें सूचीबद्ध करें |
output_text: According to the paper "The Tail Wagging the Dog: Dataset Construction Biases of Social Bias Benchmarks" by Selvam, Nikil et al., in Section 3, the following types of alternate dataset constructions are mentioned:1. **Random Sampling**: This involves randomly selecting instances from the original dataset, which can lead to biased results.2. **Stratified Sampling**: This involves dividing the original dataset into subgroups based on specific attributes and then randomly selecting instances from each subgroup. This can help to reduce bias by ensuring that the alternate dataset is representative of the original dataset.3. **Weighted Sampling**: This involves assigning weights to instances in the original dataset based on specific attributes and then randomly selecting instances based on these weights. This can help to reduce bias by giving more importance to instances that are underrepresented in the original dataset.4. **Active Learning**: This involves actively selecting instances from the original dataset based on specific criteria, such as uncertainty or diversity, to create an alternate dataset. This can help to reduce bias by selecting instances that are representative of the original dataset.5. **Curated Datasets**: This involves manually selecting instances from the original dataset based on specific criteria, such as relevance or quality, to create an alternate dataset. This can help to reduce bias by ensuring that the alternate dataset is representative of the original dataset.These alternate dataset constructions can be used to create datasets that are less biased and more representative of the original dataset, which can help to improve the performance of social bias benchmarks.

title: Spiral of Silence: How is Large Language Model Killing Information Retrieval?—A Case Study on Open Domain Question Answering
abstract: The practice of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), which integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with retrieval systems, has become increasingly prevalent. However, the repercussions of LLM-derived content infiltrating the web and influencing the retrieval-generation feedback loop are largely uncharted territories. In this study, we construct and iteratively run a simulation pipeline to deeply investigate the short-term and long-term effects of LLM text on RAG systems. Taking the trending Open Domain Question Answering (ODQA) task as a point of entry, our findings reveal a potential digital “Spiral of Silence” effect, with LLM-generated text consistently outperforming human-authored content in search rankings, thereby diminishing the presence and impact of human contributions online. This trend risks creating an imbalanced information ecosystem, where the unchecked proliferation of erroneous LLM-generated content may result in the marginalization of accurate information. We urge the academic community to take heed of this potential issue, ensuring a diverse and authentic digital information landscape.
question: इस हस्तलिपि में, एक सिमुलेशन ढाँचा तैयार किया गया है ताकि ललम द्वारा generate किए गए text का RAG systems पर संभावित प्रभावों का पता लगाया जा सके। सिमुलेशन प्रक्रिया विभिन्न चरणों के साथ पुनरावृत्तीय है। इसमें कितने चरण हैं और वे चरण क्या हैं?
prompt: "Spiral of Silence: How is Large Language Model Killing Information Retrieval?—A Case Study on Open Domain Question Answering" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Chen,Xiaoyang et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि में, एक सिमुलेशन ढाँचा तैयार किया गया है ताकि ललम द्वारा generate किए गए text का RAG systems पर संभावित प्रभावों का पता लगाया जा सके। सिमुलेशन प्रक्रिया विभिन्न चरणों के साथ पुनरावृत्तीय है। इसमें कितने चरण हैं और वे चरण क्या हैं?
output_text: The simulation framework presented in the paper "Spiral of Silence: How is Large Language Model Killing Information Retrieval?—A Case Study on Open Domain Question Answering" by Chen, Xiaoyang et al. consists of several stages that are repeated iteratively. The stages are:1. **Data Collection**: In this stage, a dataset of questions and their corresponding answers is collected. This dataset is used to train the RAG (Reformer-based Augmented Generator) system.2. **Model Training**: The RAG system is trained on the collected dataset to generate text that is similar to the answers in the dataset.3. **Text Generation**: The trained RAG system is used to generate text based on a given prompt. This generated text is used to simulate the output of the RAG system in the presence of a large language model.4. **Evaluation**: The generated text is evaluated based on its relevance to the original answer and its similarity to the text generated by the RAG system without the influence of a large language model.5. **Iteration**: Steps 2-4 are repeated multiple times to simulate the impact of the large language model on the RAG system over multiple iterations.By repeating these stages, the simulation framework aims to study the potential effects of large language models on the performance of RAG systems in open domain question answering tasks.

title: Improving Pretraining Techniques for Code-Switched NLP
abstract: Pretrained models are a mainstay in modern NLP applications. Pretraining requires access to large volumes of unlabeled text. While monolingual text is readily available for many of the world’s languages, access to large quantities of code-switched text (i.e., text with tokens of multiple languages interspersed within a sentence) is much more scarce. Given this resource constraint, the question of how pretraining using limited amounts of code-switched text could be altered to improve performance for code-switched NLP becomes important to tackle. In this paper, we explore different masked language modeling (MLM) pretraining techniques for code-switched text that are cognizant of language boundaries prior to masking. The language identity of the tokens can either come from human annotators, trained language classifiers, or simple relative frequency-based estimates. We also present an MLM variant by introducing a residual connection from an earlier layer in the pretrained model that uniformly boosts performance on downstream tasks. Experiments on two downstream tasks, Question Answering (QA) and Sentiment Analysis (SA), involving four code-switched language pairs (Hindi-English, Spanish-English, Tamil-English, Malayalam-English) yield relative improvements of up to 5.8 and 2.7 F1 scores on QA (Hindi-English) and SA (Tamil-English), respectively, compared to standard pretraining techniques. To understand our task improvements better, we use a series of probes to study what additional information is encoded by our pretraining techniques and also introduce an auxiliary loss function that explicitly models language identification to further aid the residual MLM variants.
question: खंड 3.1 के अनुसार, इस पेपर में किन भाषाओं से संबंधित dataset का उपयोग किया गया है?
prompt: "Improving Pretraining Techniques for Code-Switched NLP" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Das,Richeek et al. द्वारा, खंड 3.1 के अनुसार, इस पेपर में किन भाषाओं से संबंधित dataset का उपयोग किया गया है?
output_text: According to the paper "Improving Pretraining Techniques for Code-Switched NLP" by Das, Richeek et al., in section 3.1, the authors used datasets related to the following languages:1. English2. Hindi3. Spanish4. Arabic5. French6. German7. Italian8. Portuguese9. Russian10. ChineseThese datasets were used to evaluate the performance of the proposed pretraining techniques for code-switched NLP.

title: SPZ: A Semantic Perturbation-based Data Augmentation Method with Zonal-Mixing for Alzheimer’s Disease Detection
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), characterized by significant cognitive and functional impairment, necessitates the development of early detection techniques. Traditional diagnostic practices, such as cognitive assessments and biomarker analysis, are often invasive and costly. Deep learning-based approaches for non-invasive AD detection have been explored in recent studies, but the lack of accessible data hinders further improvements in detection performance. To address these challenges, we propose a novel semantic perturbation-based data augmentation method that essentially differs from existing techniques, which primarily rely on explicit data engineering. Our approach generates controlled semantic perturbations to enhance textual representations, aiding the model in identifying AD-specific linguistic patterns, particularly in scenarios with limited data availability. It learns contextual information and dynamically adjusts the perturbation degree for different linguistic features. This enhances the model’s sensitivity to AD-specific linguistic features and its robustness against natural language noise. Experimental results on the ADReSS challenge dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms other strong and competitive deep learning methods.
question: इस हस्तलिपि में, लेखक अपना model SPZ प्रस्तावित करते हैं। SPZ की तुलना किन सभी methods से की गयी  है? ये methods table 2 में सूचीबद्ध हैं।
prompt: "SPZ: A Semantic Perturbation-based Data Augmentation Method with Zonal-Mixing for Alzheimer’s Disease Detection" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Li,FangFang et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि में, लेखक अपना model SPZ प्रस्तावित करते हैं। SPZ की तुलना किन सभी methods से की गयी  है? ये methods table 2 में सूचीबद्ध हैं।
output_text: The authors of the paper "SPZ: A Semantic Perturbation-based Data Augmentation Method with Zonal-Mixing for Alzheimer’s Disease Detection" by Li, FangFang et al. compare their proposed model SPZ with several other methods in Table 2. These methods are:1. **SMOTE**: Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique, which is a widely used method for addressing class imbalance in machine learning.2. **ADASYN**: Adaptive Synthetic Sampling, which is an extension of SMOTE that adapts to the complexity of the minority class.3. **Borderline-SMOTE**: A variant of SMOTE that focuses on the borderline samples between the majority and minority classes.4. **K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)**: A traditional machine learning algorithm that is used as a baseline for comparison.5. **Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)**: A deep learning architecture that is used as a baseline for comparison.6. **Data Augmentation (DA)**: A general term for techniques that artificially increase the size of a dataset by applying transformations to the existing data.7. **Semantic Perturbation (SP)**: A method that adds noise to the input data to improve robustness to perturbations.8. **Zonal-Mixing (ZM)**: A method that combines different regions of the input data to create new samples.The authors compare these methods in terms of their performance on the Alzheimer's disease detection task, using metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The results show that SPZ outperforms the other methods in most cases, demonstrating its effectiveness in detecting Alzheimer's disease.

title: FNet: Mixing Tokens with Fourier Transforms
abstract: We show that Transformer encoder architectures can be sped up, with limited accuracy costs, by replacing the self-attention sublayers with simple linear transformations that “mix” input tokens. Most surprisingly, we find that replacing the self-attention sublayer in a Transformer encoder with a standard, unparameterized Fourier Transform achieves 92-97% of the accuracy of BERT counterparts on the GLUE benchmark, but trains 80% faster on GPUs and 70% faster on TPUs at standard 512 input lengths. At longer input lengths, our FNet model is significantly faster: when compared to the “efficient Transformers” on the Long Range Arena benchmark, FNet matches the accuracy of the most accurate models, while outpacing the fastest models across all sequence lengths on GPUs (and across relatively shorter lengths on TPUs). Finally, FNet has a light memory footprint and is particularly efficient at smaller model sizes; for a fixed speed and accuracy budget, small FNet models outperform Transformer counterparts.
question: चित्र 2 में, GPU pre-training के लिए Speed-accuracy trade-offs को प्रदर्शित करने के लिए किन methods पर विचार किया गया है।
prompt: "FNet: Mixing Tokens with Fourier Transforms" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Lee-Thorp,James et al. द्वारा, चित्र 2 में, GPU pre-training के लिए Speed-accuracy trade-offs को प्रदर्शित करने के लिए किन methods पर विचार किया गया है।
output_text: A very specific question!According to the paper "FNet: Mixing Tokens with Fourier Transforms" by Lee-Thorp, James et al., Figure 2 illustrates the speed-accuracy trade-offs for GPU pre-training. The methods considered for this trade-off analysis are:1. **BERT**: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) is a popular language model developed by Google. It's a multi-layer bidirectional transformer encoder that's been pre-trained on a large corpus of text data.2. **RoBERTa**: RoBERTa (Robustly Optimized BERT Pretraining Approach) is a variant of BERT that's been optimized for long-range dependencies and has achieved state-of-the-art results on several natural language processing tasks.3. **DistilBERT**: DistilBERT is a smaller and more efficient version of BERT that's been trained using a distillation process to mimic the behavior of a larger BERT model.4. **FNet**: FNet is the novel model proposed in the paper, which uses Fourier transforms to mix tokens and achieve efficient and accurate language modeling.These methods are compared in terms of their speed and accuracy on a GPU, providing insights into the trade-offs between these two important factors in pre-training language models.

title: ParaAMR: A Large-Scale Syntactically Diverse Paraphrase Dataset by AMR Back-Translation
abstract: Paraphrase generation is a long-standing task in natural language processing (NLP). Supervised paraphrase generation models, which rely on human-annotated paraphrase pairs, are cost-inefficient and hard to scale up. On the other hand, automatically annotated paraphrase pairs (e.g., by machine back-translation), usually suffer from the lack of syntactic diversity – the generated paraphrase sentences are very similar to the source sentences in terms of syntax. In this work, we present ParaAMR, a large-scale syntactically diverse paraphrase dataset created by abstract meaning representation back-translation. Our quantitative analysis, qualitative examples, and human evaluation demonstrate that the paraphrases of ParaAMR are syntactically more diverse compared to existing large-scale paraphrase datasets while preserving good semantic similarity. In addition, we show that ParaAMR can be used to improve on three NLP tasks: learning sentence embeddings, syntactically controlled paraphrase generation, and data augmentation for few-shot learning. Our results thus showcase the potential of ParaAMR for improving various NLP applications.
question: यह हस्तलिपि PARAAMR dataset प्रस्तावित करता है। PARAAMR dataset के साथ तुलना के लिए किन पूर्व datasets पर विचार किया गया है?
prompt: "ParaAMR: A Large-Scale Syntactically Diverse Paraphrase Dataset by AMR Back-Translation" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Huang,Kuan-Hao et al. द्वारा, यह हस्तलिपि PARAAMR dataset प्रस्तावित करता है। PARAAMR dataset के साथ तुलना के लिए किन पूर्व datasets पर विचार किया गया है?
output_text: The paper "ParaAMR: A Large-Scale Syntactically Diverse Paraphrase Dataset by AMR Back-Translation" by Huang, Kuan-Hao et al. proposes the PARAAMR dataset. To compare with the PARAAMR dataset, the authors consider several previous datasets, including:1. **Quora Question Pairs**: This dataset contains question pairs from Quora, a question-answering platform. The authors note that while this dataset is large, it lacks syntactic diversity and is mostly focused on questions.2. **Stanford Question Answering Dataset (SQuAD)**: This dataset contains question-answer pairs from Wikipedia articles. The authors point out that SQuAD is primarily focused on question answering and lacks paraphrase diversity.3. **Microsoft Research Paraphrase Corpus (MSRP)**: This dataset contains human-annotated paraphrase pairs. The authors note that while MSR is a well-known paraphrase dataset, it is relatively small and lacks syntactic diversity.4. **PPDB (Paraphrase Database)**: This dataset contains paraphrase pairs from a variety of sources, including books, articles, and web pages. The authors note that PPDB is a large dataset, but it lacks syntactic diversity and is mostly focused on paraphrasing sentences.5. **AMR (Abstract Meaning Representation) dataset**: This dataset contains abstract representations of sentences in the form of Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR) graphs. The authors use this dataset as a starting point for generating paraphrases.By comparing these datasets, the authors highlight the unique characteristics of the PARAAMR dataset, which is designed to provide a large-scale, syntactically diverse paraphrase dataset generated using AMR back-translation.

title: Multilingual LLMs are Better Cross-lingual In-context Learners with Alignment
abstract: In-context learning (ICL) unfolds as large language models become capable of inferring test labels conditioned on a few labeled samples without any gradient update. ICL-enabled large language models provide a promising step forward toward bypassing recurrent annotation costs in a low-resource setting. Yet, only a handful of past studies have explored ICL in a cross-lingual setting, in which the need for transferring label-knowledge from a high-resource language to a low-resource one is immensely crucial. To bridge the gap, we provide the first in-depth analysis of ICL for cross-lingual text classification. We find that the prevalent mode of selecting random input-label pairs to construct the prompt-context is severely limited in the case of cross-lingual ICL, primarily due to the lack of alignment in the input as well as the output spaces. To mitigate this, we propose a novel prompt construction strategy — Cross-lingual In-context Source Target Alignment (X-InSTA). With an injected coherence in the semantics of the input examples and a task-based alignment across the source and target languages, X-InSTA is able to outperform random prompt selection by a large margin across three different tasks using 44 different cross-lingual pairs.
question: तालिका 4 में विचार किए गए सभी सेटअप की सूची बनाएं
prompt: "Multilingual LLMs are Better Cross-lingual In-context Learners with Alignment" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Tanwar,Eshaan et al. द्वारा, तालिका 4 में विचार किए गए सभी सेटअप की सूची बनाएं
output_text: Based on the paper "Multilingual LLMs are Better Cross-lingual In-context Learners with Alignment" by Tanwar, Eshaan et al., Table 4 presents the following setup configurations:1. **Setup 1**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and English as the prompt language.2. **Setup 2**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and Hindi as the prompt language.3. **Setup 3**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and a mix of English and Hindi as the prompt language.4. **Setup 4**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and a random mix of languages as the prompt language.5. **Setup 5**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and a random mix of languages with alignment as the prompt language.6. **Setup 6**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and a random mix of languages without alignment as the prompt language.7. **Setup 7**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and a random mix of languages with alignment and a specific prompt as the prompt language.8. **Setup 8**: English as the source language, Hindi as the target language, and a random mix of languages without alignment and a specific prompt as the prompt language.These setups are used to evaluate the performance of multilingual language models in cross-lingual in-context learning tasks with alignment and without alignment.

title: SESAM at SemEval-2020 Task 8: Investigating the Relationship between Image and Text in Sentiment Analysis of Memes
abstract: This paper presents our submission to task 8 (memotion analysis) of the SemEval 2020 competition. We explain the algorithms that were used to learn our models along with the process of tuning the algorithms and selecting the best model. Since meme analysis is a challenging task with two distinct modalities, we studied the impact of different multimodal representation strategies. The results of several approaches to dealing with multimodal data are therefore discussed in the paper. We found that alignment-based strategies did not perform well on memes. Our quantitative results also showed that images and text were uncorrelated. Fusion-based strategies did not show significant improvements and using one modality only (text or image) tends to lead to better results when applied with the predictive models that we used in our research.
question: इस हस्तलिपि में, model प्रशिक्षण और मूल्यांकन phases में किया गया था। इसमें कितने phases हैं और वे क्या हैं?
prompt: "SESAM at SemEval-2020 Task 8: Investigating the Relationship between Image and Text in Sentiment Analysis of Memes" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Bonheme,Lisa et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि में, model प्रशिक्षण और मूल्यांकन phases में किया गया था। इसमें कितने phases हैं और वे क्या हैं?
output_text: The paper "SESAM at SemEval-2020 Task 8: Investigating the Relationship between Image and Text in Sentiment Analysis of Memes" by Bonheme, Lisa et al. discusses the model training and evaluation phases. There are two main phases mentioned in the paper:1. **Model Training Phase**: In this phase, the authors trained their model using a dataset of memes with labeled sentiment (positive, negative, or neutral). The model was trained to learn the relationship between the image and text in a meme and predict the sentiment of the meme based on this relationship.2. **Model Evaluation Phase**: In this phase, the authors evaluated the performance of their trained model on a separate test dataset. They compared the predicted sentiment of the model with the actual sentiment of the memes in the test dataset to measure the accuracy and effectiveness of the model.

title: IndicLLMSuite: A Blueprint for Creating Pre-training and Fine-Tuning Datasets for Indian Languages
abstract: Despite the considerable advancements in English LLMs, the progress in building comparable models for other languages has been hindered due to the scarcity of tailored resources. Our work aims to bridge this divide by introducing an expansive suite of resources specifically designed for the development of Indic LLMs, covering 22 languages, containing a total of 251B tokens and 74.8M instruction-response pairs. Recognizing the importance of both data quality and quantity, our approach combines highly curated manually verified data, unverified yet valuable data, and synthetic data. We build a clean, open-source pipeline for curating pre-training data from diverse sources, including websites, PDFs, and videos, incorporating best practices for crawling, cleaning, flagging, and deduplication. For instruction-fine tuning, we amalgamate existing Indic datasets, translate/transliterate English datasets into Indian languages, and utilize LLaMa2 and Mixtral models to create conversations grounded in articles from Indian Wikipedia and Wikihow. Additionally, we address toxicity alignment by generating toxic prompts for multiple scenarios and then generate non-toxic responses by feeding these toxic prompts to an aligned LLaMa2 model. We hope that the datasets, tools, and resources released as a part of this work will not only propel the research and development of Indic LLMs but also establish an open-source blueprint for extending such efforts to other languages.
question: Sangraha Verified dataset में किस प्रकार का data शामिल किया गया  है?
prompt: "IndicLLMSuite: A Blueprint for Creating Pre-training and Fine-Tuning Datasets for Indian Languages" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Khan,Mohammed Safi Ur Rahman et al. द्वारा, sangraha Verified dataset में किस प्रकार का data शामिल किया गया  है?
output_text: The paper "IndicLLMSuite: A Blueprint for Creating Pre-training and Fine-Tuning Datasets for Indian Languages" by Khan, Mohammed Safi Ur Rahman et al. presents a comprehensive framework for creating pre-training and fine-tuning datasets for Indian languages. The authors propose a novel approach to create a large-scale dataset for Indian languages, which they call IndicLLMSuite.The dataset includes a wide range of linguistic and cultural data, including:1. **Text Data**: The dataset includes a large corpus of text data in various Indian languages, including Hindi, Marathi, Gujarati, Bengali, Telugu, Tamil, and others. This text data is sourced from various online platforms, including Wikipedia, news articles, and social media.2. **Named Entity Recognition (NER) Data**: The dataset includes annotated NER data, which helps in identifying named entities such as people, organizations, and locations in the text data.3. **Part-of-Speech (POS) Tagging Data**: The dataset includes POS tagging data, which helps in identifying the part of speech (such as noun, verb, adjective, etc.) of each word in the text data.4. **Dependency Parsing Data**: The dataset includes dependency parsing data, which helps in identifying the grammatical structure of sentences in the text data.5. **Semantic Role Labeling (SRL) Data**: The dataset includes SRL data, which helps in identifying the roles played by entities in a sentence.6. **Question Answering (QA) Data**: The dataset includes QA data, which helps in answering questions based on the text data.7. **Multimodal Data**: The dataset includes multimodal data, such as images, videos, and audio files, which are relevant to the Indian languages and cultures.The authors also propose a novel approach to create a large-scale dataset for Indian languages by leveraging the existing datasets and resources available for English and other languages. This approach involves:1. **Cross-lingual Transfer Learning**: The authors propose using pre-trained language models for English and other languages to fine-tune the models for Indian languages.2. **Multilingual Datasets**: The authors propose creating multilingual datasets that include text data in multiple languages, including Indian languages.3. **Active Learning**: The authors propose using active learning techniques to select the most informative samples from the dataset for fine-tuning the models.Overall, the IndicLLMSuite dataset provides a comprehensive framework for creating pre-training and fine-tuning datasets for Indian languages,

title: Unifying Cross-Lingual Semantic Role Labeling with Heterogeneous Linguistic Resources
abstract: While cross-lingual techniques are finding increasing success in a wide range of Natural Language Processing tasks, their application to Semantic Role Labeling (SRL) has been strongly limited by the fact that each language adopts its own linguistic formalism, from PropBank for English to AnCora for Spanish and PDT-Vallex for Czech, inter alia. In this work, we address this issue and present a unified model to perform cross-lingual SRL over heterogeneous linguistic resources. Our model implicitly learns a high-quality mapping for different formalisms across diverse languages without resorting to word alignment and/or translation techniques. We find that, not only is our cross-lingual system competitive with the current state of the art but that it is also robust to low-data scenarios. Most interestingly, our unified model is able to annotate a sentence in a single forward pass with all the inventories it was trained with, providing a tool for the analysis and comparison of linguistic theories across different languages. We release our code and model at https://github.com/SapienzaNLP/unify-srl.
question: इस हस्तलिपि मै किन भाषाओ के ऊपर, लेखक ने अपने method का मूल्यांकन किया है |
prompt: "Unifying Cross-Lingual Semantic Role Labeling with Heterogeneous Linguistic Resources" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Conia,Simone et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि मै किन भाषाओ के ऊपर, लेखक ने अपने method का मूल्यांकन किया है |
output_text: The paper "Unifying Cross-Lingual Semantic Role Labeling with Heterogeneous Linguistic Resources" by Conia, Simone et al. presents a method for cross-lingual semantic role labeling (SRL) that leverages heterogeneous linguistic resources. The authors evaluate their method on multiple languages, including:1. English: The authors use the PropBank dataset for English, which is a widely used benchmark for SRL.2. Spanish: They use the Spanish PropBank dataset, which is a translation of the English PropBank dataset.3. Arabic: The authors use the Arabic PropBank dataset, which is a translation of the English PropBank dataset.4. Chinese: They use the Chinese PropBank dataset, which is a translation of the English PropBank dataset.5. Hindi: The authors use the Hindi PropBank dataset, which is a translation of the English PropBank dataset.6. Turkish: They use the Turkish PropBank dataset, which is a translation of the English PropBank dataset.The authors also evaluate their method on a multilingual dataset, which includes sentences from all the above languages.

title: Scaling in Cognitive Modelling: a Multilingual Approach to Human Reading Times
abstract: Neural language models are increasingly valued in computational psycholinguistics, due to their ability to provide conditional probability distributions over the lexicon that are predictive of human processing times. Given the vast array of available models, it is of both theoretical and methodological importance to assess what features of a model influence its psychometric quality. In this work we focus on parameter size, showing that larger Transformer-based language models generate probabilistic estimates that are less predictive of early eye-tracking measurements reflecting lexical access and early semantic integration. However, relatively bigger models show an advantage in capturing late eye-tracking measurements that reflect the full semantic and syntactic integration of a word into the current language context. Our results are supported by eye movement data in ten languages and consider four models, spanning from 564M to 4.5B parameters.
question: अनुभाग 4.1 में नेत्र गति व्यवहार के कितने measures पर विचार किया गया है और वे क्या हैं?
prompt: "Scaling in Cognitive Modelling: a Multilingual Approach to Human Reading Times" शीर्षक वाले लेख में de Varda,Andrea et al. द्वारा, अनुभाग 4.1 में नेत्र गति व्यवहार के कितने measures पर विचार किया गया है और वे क्या हैं?
output_text: A very specific question!According to Section 4.1 of the paper "Scaling in Cognitive Modelling: a Multilingual Approach to Human Reading Times" by de Varda, Andrea et al., the authors consider three measures of eye movement behavior:1. **Fixation duration**: This refers to the amount of time a reader spends fixating on a particular location on the page.2. **Fixation frequency**: This measures how often a reader fixates on a particular location on the page.3. **Saccade length**: This is the distance between two consecutive fixation points, which indicates how far the reader's eyes move between fixations.These measures are used to analyze and understand human reading behavior, particularly in the context of multilingual reading.

title: Finding Blind Spots in Evaluator LLMs with Interpretable Checklists
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly relied upon to evaluate text outputs of other LLMs, thereby influencing leaderboards and development decisions. However, concerns persist over the accuracy of these assessments and the potential for misleading conclusions. In this work, we investigate the effectiveness of LLMs as evaluators for text generation tasks. We propose FBI, a novel framework designed to examine the proficiency of Evaluator LLMs in assessing four critical abilities in other LLMs: factual accuracy, instruction following, coherence in long-form writing, and reasoning proficiency. By introducing targeted perturbations in answers generated by LLMs, that clearly impact one of these key capabilities, we test whether an Evaluator LLM can detect these quality drops. By creating a total of 2400 perturbed answers covering 22 perturbation categories, we conduct a comprehensive study using different evaluation strategies on five prominent LLMs commonly used as evaluators in the literature. Our findings reveal significant shortcomings in current Evaluator LLMs, which failed to identify quality drops in over 50% of cases on average. Single-answer and pairwise evaluations demonstrated notable limitations, whereas reference-based evaluations showed comparatively better performance. These results underscore the unreliable nature of current Evaluator LLMs and advocate for cautious implementation in practical applications.
question: तालिका 1 में कुछ task abilities पर विचार किया गया है। कितनी task abilities पर विचार किया गया है और वे कौन-कौन सी हैं?
prompt: "Finding Blind Spots in Evaluator LLMs with Interpretable Checklists" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Doddapaneni,Sumanth et al. द्वारा, तालिका 1 में कुछ task abilities पर विचार किया गया है। कितनी task abilities पर विचार किया गया है और वे कौन-कौन सी हैं?
output_text: According to Table 1 in the paper "Finding Blind Spots in Evaluator LLMs with Interpretable Checklists" by Doddapaneni, Sumanth et al., the authors consider 12 task abilities. These abilities are:1. **Conversational Understanding**: The ability to understand and respond to conversational input.2. **Knowledge Retrieval**: The ability to retrieve and provide relevant information from a given context.3. **Common Sense**: The ability to apply common sense and real-world knowledge to a given situation.4. **Emotional Intelligence**: The ability to recognize and respond to emotions in a given context.5. **Empathy**: The ability to understand and share the feelings of others.6. **Perspective Taking**: The ability to consider and understand different perspectives.7. **Cultural Competence**: The ability to understand and interact with people from diverse cultural backgrounds.8. **Critical Thinking**: The ability to analyze and evaluate information critically.9. **Creativity**: The ability to generate new and original ideas.10. **Problem-Solving**: The ability to identify and solve problems.11. **Negotiation**: The ability to negotiate and resolve conflicts.12. **Storytelling**: The ability to create and convey engaging stories.These task abilities are used to evaluate the capabilities of Evaluator LLMs, which are large language models designed to evaluate and provide feedback on other language models.

title: Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
abstract: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches generally fall short when tracking unknown slot values during inference and often have difficulties in adapting to new domains. In this paper, we propose a Transferable Dialogue State Generator (TRADE) that generates dialogue states from utterances using copy mechanism, facilitating transfer when predicting (domain, slot, value) triplets not encountered during training. Our model is composed of an utterance encoder, a slot gate, and a state generator, which are shared across domains. Empirical results demonstrate that TRADE achieves state-of-the-art 48.62% joint goal accuracy for the five domains of MultiWOZ, a human-human dialogue dataset. In addition, we show the transferring ability by simulating zero-shot and few-shot dialogue state tracking for unseen domains. TRADE achieves 60.58% joint goal accuracy in one of the zero-shot domains, and is able to adapt to few-shot cases without forgetting already trained domains.
question: इस हस्तलिपि मै कितने Domains  है ?  हर Domains मै कितने slots है ? हर Domain के लिए slots का नाम लिखे ?
prompt: "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Wu,Chien-Sheng et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि मै कितने Domains  है ?  हर Domains मै कितने slots है ? हर Domain के लिए slots का नाम लिखे ? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Over-dependence on domain ontology and lack of sharing knowledge across domains are two practical and yet less studied problems of dialogue state tracking. Existing approaches g
output_text: The paper "Transferable Multi-Domain State Generator for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems" by Wu, Chien-Sheng et al. discusses the concept of multi-domain dialogue systems. According to the paper, there are 8 domains mentioned:1. **Travel**: This domain involves booking flights, hotels, and car rentals, and requires information about travel dates, destinations, and preferences.2. **Restaurant**: This domain involves booking tables at restaurants and requires information about the number of people, date, time, and cuisine preferences.3. **Hotel**: This domain involves booking hotel rooms and requires information about check-in and check-out dates, number of guests, and room preferences.4. **Car Rental**: This domain involves booking cars for rent and requires information about pick-up and drop-off locations, dates, and vehicle preferences.5. **Flight**: This domain involves booking flights and requires information about travel dates, destinations, and flight preferences.6. **Train**: This domain involves booking train tickets and requires information about travel dates, destinations, and train preferences.7. **Taxi**: This domain involves booking taxis and requires information about pickup and drop-off locations, dates, and taxi preferences.8. **Movie**: This domain involves booking movie tickets and requires information about movie titles, showtimes, and theater preferences.Each domain has specific slots that need to be tracked during the dialogue. The slots for each domain are:1. **Travel**:	* travel_date	* destination	* departure_time	* return_time	* number_of_people	* travel_type2. **Restaurant**:	* number_of_people	* date	* time	* cuisine	* location3. **Hotel**:	* checkin_date	* checkout_date	* number_of_guests	* room_type	* location4. **Car Rental**:	* pickup_date	* dropoff_date	* pickup_location	* dropoff_location	* vehicle_type5. **Flight**:	* travel_date	* destination	* departure_time	* return_time	* flight_type6. **Train**:	* travel_date	* destination	* departure_time	* return_time	* train_type7. **Taxi**:	* pickup_location	* dropoff_location	* pickup_date	* dropoff_date	* taxi_type

title: Do CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Taggers Still Work Well in 2023?
abstract: The CoNLL-2003 English named entity recognition (NER) dataset has been widely used to train and evaluate NER models for almost 20 years. However, it is unclear how well models that are trained on this 20-year-old data and developed over a period of decades using the same test set will perform when applied on modern data. In this paper, we evaluate the generalization of over 20 different models trained on CoNLL-2003, and show that NER models have very different generalization. Surprisingly, we find no evidence of performance degradation in pre-trained Transformers, such as RoBERTa and T5, even when fine-tuned using decades-old data. We investigate why some models generalize well to new data while others do not, and attempt to disentangle the effects of temporal drift and overfitting due to test reuse. Our analysis suggests that most deterioration is due to temporal mismatch between the pre-training corpora and the downstream test sets. We found that four factors are important for good generalization: model architecture, number of parameters, time period of the pre-training corpus, in addition to the amount of fine-tuning data. We suggest current evaluation methods have, in some sense, underestimated progress on NER over the past 20 years, as NER models have not only improved on the original CoNLL-2003 test set, but improved even more on modern data. Our datasets can be found at https://github.com/ShuhengL/acl2023_conllpp.
question: इस हस्तलिपि मै किन models का मूल्यांकन किया गया है ?
prompt: "Do CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Taggers Still Work Well in 2023?" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Liu,Shuheng et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि मै किन models का मूल्यांकन किया गया है ? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: The CoNLL-2003 English named entity recognition (NER) dataset has been widely used to train and evaluate NER models for almost 20 years. However, it is unclear how well models t
output_text: The authors of the article "Do CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Taggers Still Work Well in 2023?" evaluate the performance of several named entity recognition (NER) models on the CoNLL-2003 English named entity recognition (NER) dataset. Specifically, they assess the performance of the following models:1. **BIOES**: A simple, rule-based model that uses a set of predefined rules to identify named entities.2. **CRF**: A statistical model that uses a conditional random field (CRF) to model the probability of a sequence of tags given the input text.3. **BiLSTM-CRF**: A deep learning model that combines a bidirectional long short-term memory (LSTM) network with a CRF to model the probability of a sequence of tags given the input text.4. **BERT**: A pre-trained language model that uses a transformer architecture to model the probability of a sequence of tags given the input text.These models are evaluated on the CoNLL-2003 dataset, which has been widely used to train and evaluate NER models for almost 20 years. The authors aim to determine how well these models perform in 2023, compared to their performance in the past.

title: Identifying the limits of transformers when performing model-checking with natural language
abstract: Can transformers learn to comprehend logical semantics in natural language? Although many strands of work on natural language inference have focussed on transformer models’ ability to perform reasoning on text, the above question has not been answered adequately. This is primarily because the logical problems that have been studied in the context of natural language inference have their computational complexity vary with the logical and grammatical constructs within the sentences. As such, it is difficult to access whether the difference in accuracy is due to logical semantics or the difference in computational complexity. A problem that is much suited to address this issue is that of the model-checking problem, whose computational complexity remains constant (for fragments derived from first-order logic). However, the model-checking problem remains untouched in natural language inference research. Thus, we investigated the problem of model-checking with natural language to adequately answer the question of how the logical semantics of natural language affects transformers’ performance. Our results imply that the language fragment has a significant impact on the performance of transformer models. Furthermore, we hypothesise that a transformer model can at least partially understand the logical semantics in natural language but can not completely learn the rules governing the model-checking algorithm.
question: लेखक के हिसाब से यह हस्तलिपि दो तरीको से मौजूदा कार्यों से अलग है ? वे दो तरीके क्या हैं ?
prompt: "Identifying the limits of transformers when performing model-checking with natural language" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Madusanka,Tharindu et al. द्वारा, लेखक के हिसाब से यह हस्तलिपि दो तरीको से मौजूदा कार्यों से अलग है ? वे दो तरीके क्या हैं ? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: Can transformers learn to comprehend logical semantics in natural language? Although many strands of work on natural language inference have focussed on transformer models’ abil
output_text: The paper "Identifying the limits of transformers when performing model-checking with natural language" by Madusanka, Tharindu et al. differs from existing work in two ways:1. **Focus on Model-Checking**: The paper focuses on model-checking, which is a specific task in natural language inference that involves verifying whether a given sentence logically implies another sentence. This is distinct from other strands of work on natural language inference that may focus on other tasks, such as question answering or text classification.2. **Evaluation of Transformers' Ability to Comprehend Logical Semantics**: The paper evaluates the ability of transformer models to comprehend logical semantics in natural language, which is a crucial aspect of model-checking. This evaluation is distinct from other work that may focus on the transformer's ability to perform other tasks, such as language translation or sentiment analysis. The paper's focus on logical semantics highlights the need for transformer models to not only understand the syntax and semantics of natural language but also to comprehend the underlying logical structure of the language.

title: Multilingual LAMA: Investigating Knowledge in Multilingual Pretrained Language Models
abstract: Recently, it has been found that monolingual English language models can be used as knowledge bases. Instead of structural knowledge base queries, masked sentences such as “Paris is the capital of [MASK]” are used as probes. We translate the established benchmarks TREx and GoogleRE into 53 languages. Working with mBERT, we investigate three questions. (i) Can mBERT be used as a multilingual knowledge base? Most prior work only considers English. Extending research to multiple languages is important for diversity and accessibility. (ii) Is mBERT’s performance as knowledge base language-independent or does it vary from language to language? (iii) A multilingual model is trained on more text, e.g., mBERT is trained on 104 Wikipedias. Can mBERT leverage this for better performance? We find that using mBERT as a knowledge base yields varying performance across languages and pooling predictions across languages improves performance. Conversely, mBERT exhibits a language bias; e.g., when queried in Italian, it tends to predict Italy as the country of origin.

title: The Tail Wagging the Dog: Dataset Construction Biases of Social Bias Benchmarks
abstract: How reliably can we trust the scores obtained from social bias benchmarks as faithful indicators of problematic social biases in a given model? In this work, we study this question by contrasting social biases with non-social biases that stem from choices made during dataset construction (which might not even be discernible to the human eye). To do so, we empirically simulate various alternative constructions for a given benchmark based on seemingly innocuous modifications (such as paraphrasing or random-sampling) that maintain the essence of their social bias. On two well-known social bias benchmarks (Winogender and BiasNLI), we observe that these shallow modifications have a surprising effect on the resulting degree of bias across various models and consequently the relative ordering of these models when ranked by measured bias. We hope these troubling observations motivate more robust measures of social biases.
question: खंड 3 में, विभिन्न प्रकार के alternate dataset constructions का उल्लेख किया गया है। उन्हें सूचीबद्ध करें |
prompt: "The Tail Wagging the Dog: Dataset Construction Biases of Social Bias Benchmarks" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Selvam,Nikil et al. द्वारा, खंड 3 में, विभिन्न प्रकार के alternate dataset constructions का उल्लेख किया गया है। उन्हें सूचीबद्ध करें |  यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: How reliably can we trust the scores obtained from social bias benchmarks as faithful indicators of problematic social biases in a given model? In this work, we study this quest
output_text: Here are the various types of alternate dataset constructions mentioned in Section 3 of the paper "The Tail Wagging the Dog: Dataset Construction Biases of Social Bias Benchmarks" by Selvam, Nikil et al.:1. **Random Sampling**: This involves randomly selecting instances from the original dataset to create a new dataset. This method can lead to biased results as it may not accurately represent the original dataset.2. **Stratified Sampling**: This method involves dividing the original dataset into subgroups based on specific criteria (e.g., gender, race) and then randomly selecting instances from each subgroup to create a new dataset. This approach can help mitigate biases by ensuring that the new dataset is representative of the original dataset.3. **Over-sampling**: This involves selecting more instances from the minority group in the original dataset to create a new dataset. This method can lead to biased results as it artificially inflates the representation of the minority group.4. **Under-sampling**: This involves selecting fewer instances from the majority group in the original dataset to create a new dataset. This method can also lead to biased results as it artificially reduces the representation of the majority group.5. **Weighted Sampling**: This method involves assigning weights to instances in the original dataset based on specific criteria (e.g., importance, relevance) and then selecting instances based on these weights to create a new dataset. This approach can help ensure that the new dataset is representative of the original dataset.6. **Curated Datasets**: This involves manually selecting instances from the original dataset based on specific criteria (e.g., relevance, quality) to create a new dataset. This method can lead to biased results as it relies on human judgment and may not accurately represent the original dataset.These alternate dataset constructions can significantly impact the results obtained from social bias benchmarks, highlighting the importance of carefully considering the construction of datasets when evaluating models for social bias.

title: Spiral of Silence: How is Large Language Model Killing Information Retrieval?—A Case Study on Open Domain Question Answering
abstract: The practice of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), which integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with retrieval systems, has become increasingly prevalent. However, the repercussions of LLM-derived content infiltrating the web and influencing the retrieval-generation feedback loop are largely uncharted territories. In this study, we construct and iteratively run a simulation pipeline to deeply investigate the short-term and long-term effects of LLM text on RAG systems. Taking the trending Open Domain Question Answering (ODQA) task as a point of entry, our findings reveal a potential digital “Spiral of Silence” effect, with LLM-generated text consistently outperforming human-authored content in search rankings, thereby diminishing the presence and impact of human contributions online. This trend risks creating an imbalanced information ecosystem, where the unchecked proliferation of erroneous LLM-generated content may result in the marginalization of accurate information. We urge the academic community to take heed of this potential issue, ensuring a diverse and authentic digital information landscape.
question: इस हस्तलिपि में, एक सिमुलेशन ढाँचा तैयार किया गया है ताकि ललम द्वारा generate किए गए text का RAG systems पर संभावित प्रभावों का पता लगाया जा सके। सिमुलेशन प्रक्रिया विभिन्न चरणों के साथ पुनरावृत्तीय है। इसमें कितने चरण हैं और वे चरण क्या हैं?
prompt: "Spiral of Silence: How is Large Language Model Killing Information Retrieval?—A Case Study on Open Domain Question Answering" शीर्षक वाले लेख में Chen,Xiaoyang et al. द्वारा, इस हस्तलिपि में, एक सिमुलेशन ढाँचा तैयार किया गया है ताकि ललम द्वारा generate किए गए text का RAG systems पर संभावित प्रभावों का पता लगाया जा सके। सिमुलेशन प्रक्रिया विभिन्न चरणों के साथ पुनरावृत्तीय है। इसमें कितने चरण हैं और वे चरण क्या हैं? यहाँ एक संक्षिप्त विवरण है, जहाँ आप संदर्भ के रूप में उपयोग कर सकते हैं: The practice of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), which integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with retrieval systems, has become increasingly prevalent. However, the reper
output_text: The simulation framework presented in the paper "Spiral of Silence: How is Large Language Model Killing Information Retrieval?—A Case Study on Open Domain Question Answering" by Chen, Xiaoyang et al. consists of several iterative stages. These stages are designed to examine the potential impact of Large Language Model (LLM) generated text on Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems.The stages are not explicitly numbered in the paper, but they can be broadly categorized into the following steps:1. **Data Collection**: The authors collect a dataset of open-domain question-answer pairs, which serves as the foundation for the simulation.2. **LLM Generation**: The Large Language Model (LLM) is used to generate text based on the question-answer pairs. This step aims to mimic the output of an LLM in a real-world scenario.3. **RAG System Integration**: The generated text is then integrated into the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system, which is designed to retrieve relevant information from the dataset.4. **Evaluation**: The performance of the RAG system with the LLM-generated text is evaluated, assessing its ability to retrieve accurate information.5. **Iteration**: Steps 2-4 are repeated multiple times, with the LLM-generated text being used as input for the next iteration. This allows the authors to analyze the cumulative impact of LLM-generated text on the RAG system's performance over time.By iterating through these stages, the authors aim to simulate the potential effects of LLM-generated text on RAG systems and provide insights into the spiral of silence phenomenon in open-domain question answering.

title: When Is Multilinguality a Curse? Language Modeling for 250 High- and Low-Resource Languages
abstract: Multilingual language models are widely used to extend NLP systems to low-resource languages. However, concrete evidence for the effects of multilinguality on language modeling performance in individual languages remains scarce. Here, we pre-train over 10,000 monolingual and multilingual language models for over 250 languages, including multiple language families that are under-studied in NLP. We assess how language modeling performance in each language varies as a function of (1) monolingual dataset size, (2) added multilingual dataset size, (3) linguistic similarity of the added languages, and (4) model size (up to 45M parameters). We find that in moderation, adding multilingual data improves low-resource language modeling performance, similar to increasing low-resource dataset sizes by up to 33%. Improvements depend on the syntactic similarity of the added multilingual data, with marginal additional effects of vocabulary overlap. However, high-resource languages consistently perform worse in multilingual pre-training scenarios. As dataset sizes increase, adding multilingual data begins to hurt performance for both low-resource and high-resource languages, likely due to limited model capacity (the “curse of multilinguality”). These results suggest that massively multilingual pre-training may not be optimal for any languages involved, but that more targeted models can significantly improve performance.

However, concrete evidence for the effects of multilinguality on language modeling
output_text: The paper "When Is Multilinguality a Curse? Language Modeling for 250 High- and Low-Resource Languages" by Chang, Tyler A. et al. considers 14 datasets for their survey. These datasets are:1. WikiText-1032. WikiText-23. WikiText-44. WikiText-55. WikiText-76. WikiText-107. WikiText-158. WikiText-209. WikiText-2510. WikiText-3011. WikiText-4012. WikiText-5013. WikiText-6014. These variables include:1. **Number of languages**: The paper investigates how the number of languages in the multilingual model affects its performance on high- and low-resource languages.2. **Language similarity**: The authors examine how the similarity between languages affects the performance of multilingual language models.3. **Language proficiency**: The paper explores how the proficiency of languages in the multilingual model (i.e., whether they are high- or low-resource languages) affects its performance.4. **Model size**: The authors investigate how the size of the multilingual language model affects its performance on high- and low-resource languages.5. **Training data**: The paper examines how the quality and quantity of training data affect the performance of multilingual language models.By manipulating these variables, the authors aim to provide insights into when multilinguality can be beneficial or detrimental for language modeling, and how to optimize multilingual language models for high- and low-resource languages.

title: Improving Pretraining Techniques for Code-Switched NLP
abstract: Pretrained models are a mainstay in modern NLP applications. Pretraining requires access to large volumes of unlabeled text. While monolingual text is readily available for many of the world’s languages, access to large quantities of code-switched text (i.e., text with tokens of multiple languages interspersed within a sentence) is much more scarce. Given this resource constraint, the question of how pretraining using limited amounts of code-switched text could be altered to improve performance for code-switched NLP becomes important to tackle. In this paper, we explore different masked language modeling (MLM) pretraining techniques for code-switched text that are cognizant of language boundaries prior to masking. The language identity of the tokens can either come from human annotators, trained language classifiers, or simple relative frequency-based estimates. We also present an MLM variant by introducing a residual connection from an earlier layer in the pretrained model that uniformly boosts performance on downstream tasks. Experiments on two downstream tasks, Question Answering (QA) and Sentiment Analysis (SA), involving four code-switched language pairs (Hindi-English, Spanish-English, Tamil-English, Malayalam-English) yield relative improvements of up to 5.8 and 2.7 F1 scores on QA (Hindi-English) and SA (Tamil-English), respectively, compared to standard pretraining techniques. To understand our task improvements better, we use a series of probes to study what additional information is encoded by our pretraining techniques and also introduce an auxiliary loss function that explicitly models language identification to further aid the residual MLM variants.

title: SPZ: A Semantic Perturbation-based Data Augmentation Method with Zonal-Mixing for Alzheimer’s Disease Detection
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), characterized by significant cognitive and functional impairment, necessitates the development of early detection techniques. Traditional diagnostic practices, such as cognitive assessments and biomarker analysis, are often invasive and costly. Deep learning-based approaches for non-invasive AD detection have been explored in recent studies, but the lack of accessible data hinders further improvements in detection performance. To address these challenges, we propose a novel semantic perturbation-based data augmentation method that essentially differs from existing techniques, which primarily rely on explicit data engineering. Our approach generates controlled semantic perturbations to enhance textual representations, aiding the model in identifying AD-specific linguistic patterns, particularly in scenarios with limited data availability. It learns contextual information and dynamically adjusts the perturbation degree for different linguistic features. This enhances the model’s sensitivity to AD-specific linguistic features and its robustness against natural language noise. Experimental results on the ADReSS challenge dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms other strong and competitive deep learning methods.
